diagrams.description: Computer networking history began in the 1960s with ARPANET, the precursor to the internet, developed by the U.S. Department of Defense. 1969 saw the first ARPANET message sent. The 1970s introduced Ethernet technology and TCP/IP protocol development. 1983 marked ARPANET's transition to TCP/IP, creating the modern internet foundation. 1989 brought Tim Berners-Lee's World Wide Web invention. The 1990s saw explosive internet commercialization and browser development (Mosaic, Netscape). 1997 introduced Wi-Fi (802.11). The 2000s witnessed broadband expansion, social networks, and cloud computing emergence. 2010s advanced mobile networks (4G/LTE), IoT proliferation. The 2020s continue with 5G deployment, edge computing, and AI-driven network management.
diagrams.mermaid_code: timeline title Computer Networks Evolution section 1960s-70s 1960s : ARPANET development begins : First packet-switching network 1969 : First ARPANET message sent 1970s : Ethernet technology introduced : TCP/IP protocol development section 1980s 1983 : ARPANET adopts TCP/IP : Modern internet foundation 1989 : World Wide Web invented : Tim Berners-Lee's innovation section 1990s 1990s : Internet commercialization : Web browsers emerge 1997 : Wi-Fi (802.11) introduced section 2000s 2000s : Broadband expansion : Social networks rise : Cloud computing emerges section 2010s-Present 2010s : 4G/LTE mobile networks : IoT proliferation 2020s : 5G deployment : Edge computing : AI-driven management
